title: 106_hr942
content: The "Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act" is a new legislation that revises duopoly rules in the Communications Act of 1934. It introduces a new section, SEC. 338, to address duopoly regulations. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act revises duopoly rules by allowing ownership of two stations with overlapping coverage contours in separate television markets or two television stations within the same market if one is a UHF station. Existing local marketing agreements between stations in the same market are protected, and ownership of two VHF stations may be permitted in exceptional circumstances. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act allows ownership of two stations in separate television markets with overlapping coverage contours or two television stations within the same market under certain conditions. In exceptional circumstances, ownership of two VHF stations may be permitted by the Commission. SEC. 3. CROSS-OWNERSHIP LIMITATIONS. The Federal Communications Commission is required to make rule changes to eliminate restrictions on granting broadcast station licenses based on ownership of a daily newspaper and to remove the one-to-a-market rule. Additionally, minority voting stock interests will not be considered a cognizable interest if one holder owns more than 50% of the voting stock. Cable cross-ownership limitations under the Communications Act of 1934 are also amended. The Federal Communications Commission is amending cable cross-ownership limitations and dual-network rules to allow ownership of broadcasting stations and cable systems in the same community, as well as permitting television broadcast stations to affiliate with multiple networks under certain conditions. The Federal Communications Commission is amending cable cross-ownership limitations and dual-network rules to allow ownership of broadcasting stations and cable systems in the same community, as well as permitting television broadcast stations to affiliate with multiple networks under certain conditions. Entities offering program services to affiliated television licensees in multiple states are subject to specific regulations, with a deadline of 90 days for the FCC to complete necessary modifications. SEC. 4 amends the Telecommunications Act of 1996 to increase the ownership limit from 35% to 45%. The Federal Communications Commission must implement this change within 90 days. SEC. 5 addresses reciprocal treatment of foreign ownership restrictions. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership in broadcast and common carrier licenses. No licenses shall be granted to aliens, foreign corporations, or corporations with significant foreign ownership. The Communications Act of 1934 prohibits granting broadcast and common carrier licenses to corporations with significant foreign ownership, as determined by the FCC in the interest of the public. Foreign countries that allow US ownership in broadcast stations may receive reciprocal treatment. The FCC prohibits granting broadcast licenses to corporations with significant foreign ownership. If a corporation seeking a broadcast license has more than one-fourth of its capital stock owned by US persons, the FCC may allow foreign ownership equal to what US citizens are permitted in that foreign country. The FCC prohibits granting broadcast licenses to corporations with significant foreign ownership. The Commission may allow foreign ownership up to 40 percent of voting stock if the corporation has more than one-fourth of its capital stock owned by US persons. The term 'United States person' includes corporations organized under state laws, US citizen individuals, US government entities, and their representatives.
